questions.question: Question 1: Which is the most common subtype of Hodgkin's lymphoma?
questions.explanation:
Nodular sclerosis is the most common type of Hodgkin's lymphoma, while mixed cellularity is 
most common in India. The incidence of nodular sclerosis is equal in men and women. It commonly involves the lower 
cervical, supraclavicular, and mediastinal lymph nodes. It commonly affects adolescents and 
young adults. It has an excellent prognosis. Mixed-cellularity Hodgkin lymphoma is seen in patients older than 50 years of age. There is a 
male predominance. The image given below shows the histology of nodular sclerosis showing a lacunar variant 
of Reed–Sternberg cells 489 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 2: A lymph node biopsy specimen of a patient shows giant cells with an owl-eyed appearance. 
Which of the following statements is incorrect with respect to the diagnosis in this case?

options.a: Single axial group of lymph nodes is affected
options.b: Spleen is the first extranodal tissue to be involved

questions.explanation:
An owl-eyed appearance of giant cells in lymph nodes is characteristic of Hodgkin's lymphoma 
(HL). Mesenteric lymph nodes are infrequently involved in HL. Hodgkin’s lymphoma is a group of lymphoid neoplasms arising in a single group of lymph 
nodes. Extranodal involvement is uncommon. However, if it spreads from the nodes, the first 
organ to be involved is the spleen, then the liver, and finally the bone marrow. This pattern of 
spread is known as the contiguous spread. This predictable route of spread is important clinically as it aids in staging and prognosis as well 
as treatment of HL.

questions.question: Question 3: Activation of which of the following is a common event in classical Hodgkin's lymphoma?
questions.explanation:
Activation of the transcription factor NF-B is a common event in classical Hodgkin's lymphoma 
(HL). NF-B may be activated by Epstein–Barr virus (EBV) infection. EBV+ tumor cells express latent 
membrane protein-1 (LMP-1) which upregulates NF-B. Activation of NF-B may occur in 
EBV tumors as a result of the acquired loss-of-function mutations in TNF alpha-induced protein 3 
(TNFAIP3). Activation of NF-B by EBV rescues crippled germinal center B cells that cannot express Igs from 
apoptosis, eventually leading to the formation of Reed–Sternberg cells.

questions.question:
Question 4: Copy-number gains of which proto-oncogene on chromosome 2p are common in Hodgkin 
lymphoma?
questions.explanation:
490 
Sold by @itachibot Copy-number gains in the REL proto-oncogene on chromosome 2p are particularly common in 
Hodgkin's lymphoma. It may also contribute to increased NF- activity. Reed-Sternberg cells are aneuploid and possess diverse clonal chromosomal aberrations. Note: the MYC gene, commonly associated with Burkitt lymphoma is present on chromosome 8.

questions.question: Question 5: In which of the following lesions can we see the Reed-Sternberg-like cells?
questions.explanation:
Reed–Sternberg-like cells (RSLC) can be seen in the following: • Infectious mononucleosis • Large-cell non-Hodgkin lymphomas (most common in immunoblastic NHL) • Solid tissue cancers While Reed-Sternberg cells (RS cells) are seen in Hodgkin’s lymphoma, there can be presence of 
Reed-Sternberg like cells which that may have morphologic features resembling RS cells. Diagnostic Reed–Sternberg cells are large cells with multiple nuclei or a single nucleus with 
multiple nuclear lobes, each with a large inclusion-like nucleolus, about the size of a small 
lymphocyte with abundant cytoplasm (owl-eye appearance). The image given below shows the classic Reed Sternberg cells.

questions.question: Question 6: Which of the following is not a variant of the Reed-Sternberg cell?
questions.explanation:
Monomorphic is not a variant of RS cell. Reed–Sternberg cell (RS cell) is the characteristic tumor giant cell of Hodgkin Lymphoma. It is 
derived from the germinal center B cell. It has a classic owl-eyed appearance due to the presence 
of a symmetric or mirror-image bilobed nucleus, with prominent nucleoli surrounded by a clear 491 
Sold by @itachibot space. It has the following variants: • Lacunar • Classic • L&H Popcorn cells • Pleomorphic • Mononuclear RS cells should be present in a background of non-neoplastic inflammatory cells like lymphocytes, 
plasma cells, and eosinophils, to make a diagnosis of Hodgkin’s lymphoma. The image given below shows the diagnostic Reed-Sternberg cell, with two nuclear lobes, large 
inclusion-like nucleoli, and abundant cytoplasm, surrounded by lymphocytes, macrophages, and 
an eosinophil. The image below shows Reed-Sternberg cell, mononuclear variant. 492 
Sold by @itachibot The image below shows Reed-Sternberg cell, lacunar variant. This variant has a folded or 
multilobated nucleus and lies within an open space, which is an artefact created by disruption of 
the cytoplasm during tissue sectioning. The image below shows the Reed-Sternberg cell, lymphohistiocytic variant. Several such variants 
with multiple infolded nuclear membranes, small nucleoli, fine chromatin, and abundant pale 
cytoplasm are present.

questions.question:
Question 7: A patient with generalized lymphadenopathy and Pel-Ebstein fever is diagnosed with 
Hodgkin's lymphoma. Which of the following is a characteristic finding seen in this 
condition?

options.a: Pain in nodes relieved by alcohol
options.b: Pain in nodes aggravated by alcohol

questions.explanation:
In the case of Hodgkin's Lymphoma, the pain in the lymph nodes aggravates following the intake 
of alcohol. 493 
Sold by @itachibot Clinical features of HL: • Painless enlargement of lymph nodes is the most common presenting symptom. • Cyclical fever (Pel–Ebstein fever) - cyclical increase, which then decreases over an average period 
of one or two weeks and night sweats in disseminated disease. This cyclical fever may be due to 
the release of cytokines. A unique paraneoplastic syndrome associated with Hodgkin's lymphoma is the occurrence of pain 
in the affected lymph nodes during alcohol consumption. This has been attributed to the 
enlargement of the affected lymph nodes following alcohol consumption, which stretches the 
capsule of the lymph node and produces pain.

questions.question:
Question 8: A lymph node biopsy sample of a patient showed Reed-Sternberg cells that were CD15 & 
CD30 negative. Which of the variants of Hodgkin lymphoma is the patient most likely to 
have? 483 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario with biopsy findings of CD15 and CD30 negative Reed–Sternberg cell is 
suggestive of nodular lymphocyte-predominant Hodgkin lymphoma. The Reed–Sternberg cells are positive for CD15 and CD30 for most subtypes, except in 
lymphocyte-predominant HL, in which the neoplastic cells stains for CD20 and BCL-6.

questions.question: Question 9: Which subtype of Hodgkin's lymphoma has an incidence as shown in the graph given below?
questions.explanation:
The given graph shows a disease with a biphasic incidence which is characteristically seen in 
mixed cellularity type of Hodgkin lymphoma. It has a male predominance, biphasic incidence, peaking in young adults and again in adults older 
than 55 years. It has more systemic symptoms like night sweats and weight loss. There is diffuse 
involvement of the entire lymph node. It consists of a mixture of cells composed of T cells, 
eosinophils, plasma cells, and benign macrophages mixed with Reed–Sternberg cells. The 
mononuclear variant and diagnostic Reed–Sternberg cells are seen in this type. Reed–Sternberg cell is infected with Epstein–Barr virus in 70% of cases. It has very good 
prognosis. Image given below shows mononuclear variant of RS cell. 494 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 10: Which subtype of Hodgkin's lymphoma is associated with older age, systemic symptoms, and 
advanced tumor stage?
questions.explanation:
Mixed-cellularity Hodgkin's lymphoma is associated with older age, systemic symptoms like night 
sweats and weight loss, and advanced tumor stage. It has a biphasic incidence peaking in young adults and again in adults more than 55 years of age. 
It also has a strong association with HIV. It is more common in males than females. Nonetheless, the overall prognosis is very good.

questions.question:
Question 11: The given histological findings were noted on a lymph node biopsy of a patient with 
lymphadenopathy. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given image shows a lacunar variant of Reed–Sternberg cell. These are common in 
the nodular sclerosis subtype of Hodgkin lymphoma. Subtypes of Hodgkin's lymphoma along with their characteristic types of RS cells is given below: Diagnostic cells in histology 
Immunophenotype Hodgkin lymphoma (subty 
pes) Nodular sclerosis 
Lacunar variant 
CD 15+, CD 30 + CD 15+, CD 30 + Mixed cellularity 
Mononuclear and Diagnostic 
RS cells (70% EBV +) CD 15+, CD 30 + Lymphocyte Rich 
Mononuclear and Diagnostic 
RS cells (40% EBV +) CD 15+, CD 30 + Lymphocyte Depletion 
Reticular variant; (most EBV 
+) CD 20+, BCL6+CD 15 -, CD 3 
0 - Lymphocyte predominance 
Lymphocytic and histiocytic 
variant, popcorn cells (EBV -) 495 
Sold by @itachibot The image given below shows nodular sclerosis type of HL with lacunar cells.

questions.question:
Question 12: Which of the following statements is false regarding the nodular sclerosis variant of Hodgkin 
lymphoma?

options.a: Reed-Sternberg cells are positive for PAX 5
options.b: It is uncommonly associated with Epstein Barr Virus
options.d: Reed-Sternberg cells are positive for CD45

questions.explanation:
Reed–Sternberg cells in nodular sclerosis variant of Hodgkin lymphoma (HL) are negative for 
CD45. It is the most common variant. These are characterized by the presence of lacunar variant Reed–Sternberg cells and the 
deposition of collagen bands. These bands divide involved lymph nodes into circumscribed 
nodules. The Reed-Sternberg cells are found in a polymorphous background of T cells, eosinophils, plasma 
cells, and macrophages. Diagnostic Reed-Sternberg cells are often uncommon. The Reed–Sternberg cells are positive for PAX5 (a B-cell transcription factor), CD15, and CD30, 
and negative for other B-cell markers, T-cell markers, and CD45 (leukocyte common 
antigen). This subtype is uncommonly associated with Epstein–Barr virus (EBV). Involvement of the spleen, liver, bone marrow and other organs and tissues can occur later in the 
disease. The prognosis is excellent.

questions.question:
Question 13: Lymph node biopsy of which of the following variants of Hodgkin lymphoma will show the 
maximum area of necrosis? 485 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The lymphocyte-depleted subtype of Hodgkin lymphoma is associated with maximum necrosis of 
the lymph nodes. Lymphocyte-depleted is the least common type (<5%). It is seen in older and HIV-infected 
individuals and can present with systemic symptoms. There is a paucity of lymphocytes and a 496 
Sold by @itachibot relative abundance of Reed–Sternberg (RS) cells or their pleomorphic variants. RS cells are CD15+ 
and CD30+ RS cells are infected with Epstein–Barr virus (EBV) in 90% of the cases. It has a poor 
prognosis.

questions.question: Question 14: Which subtype of Hodgkin's lymphoma is most commonly associated with HIV?
questions.explanation:
The Mixed cellularity subtype of Hodgkin's lymphoma (HL) is most commonly associated with 
HIV. Note: Although both mixed cellularity and lymphocyte depletion are seen in patients with HIV, 
mixed cellularity is more commonly associated with HIV.

questions.question:
Question 15: A 15-year-old male patient came to the OPD with cervical lymph node enlargement. The 
biopsy was examined, which showed a variant of the Reed-Sternberg cell given in the image. 
Which of the following types of Hodgkin's lymphoma frequently has this cell in its histology?
questions.explanation:
The given image shows the lymphohistiocytic variant (L&H) of Reed–Sternberg (RS) cell. It is 
seen frequently in lymphocyte-predominant Hodgkin's lymphoma. The cell has the following features: • Polypoid nuclei • Inconspicuous nucleoli • Moderately abundant cytoplasm As it resembles popcorn in its morphology it is also termed popcorn cell. Note: A unique paraneoplastic syndrome associated with Hodgkin's lymphoma is the occurrence 
of pain in the affected lymph nodes during alcohol consumption. This has been attributed to the 
enlargement of the affected lymph nodes following alcohol consumption, which stretches the 
capsule of the lymph node and produces pain.

questions.question:
Question 16: A young male presented with cervical lymphadenopathy. The biopsy of the lymph node 
showed RS cells with vague nodule formation and a background of reactive T-lymphocytes. 
The cells were positive for CD20, LCA, EMA and negative for CD 15 and CD30. What is the 
diagnosis?

options.c: T cell rich B cell lymphoma

questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of nodular lymphocyte-predominant Hodgkin's 
lymphoma (NLPHL). Axial group (cervical) lymphadenopathy and along with the L&H variant of Reed-Sternberg 
cells is characteristic. RS cells are neoplastic giant cells. In NLPHL, the cells have vague nodular formation. 
Immunophenotyping is positive for CD20 (B cell-associated), LCA (CD45), EMA (epithelial 
marker), and negative for CD15 (monocyte or macrophage-associated) and CD30 (activation 
marker). The image given below shows the L&H variant of RS cells seen in NLPHL. 497 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 17: In a patient with lymphocyte-predominant Hodgkin lymphoma, cells are found to be positive 
for which of the following marker?
questions.explanation:
Nodular-lymphocyte predominant Hodgkin Lymphomas have Reed Sternberg cells(aka L&H 
CELL) that are BCL-6 positive & CD 20 positive and CD 15 & CD 30 negative. Note: • CD30 is the most sensitive marker of Reed–Sternberg cell. • PAX5 is the most specific marker of Reed–Sternberg cell.

questions.question: Question 18: Which of the following is incorrect about lymphocyte-predominant Hodgkin's lymphoma?

options.a: It can progress to a tumor resembling DLBCL
options.c: The bone marrow involvement is rare
options.d: A strong association with EBV is seen

questions.explanation:
Lymphocyte-predominant Hodgkin's lymphoma (HL) is not associated with Epstein–Barr virus 
(EBV) infection. In 3% to 5% of cases, this type transforms into a tumor resembling diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. A majority of patients are males, usually younger than 35 years of age, who typically present with 
cervical or axillary lymphadenopathy. Mediastinal and bone marrow involvement is rare. This form of HL is more likely to recur than the classical subtypes, but the prognosis is excellent.

questions.question:
Question 19: A 23-year-old man is diagnosed to have Stage II (A) Hodgkin's lymphoma. What staging 
system was most likely used to classify the tumor of this patient?
questions.explanation:
Clinical staging of both Hodgkin and Non-Hodgkin lymphoma is done by Ann-Arbor 
classification. Option B: Masaoka staging is used for thymoma. 498 
Sold by @itachibot Option C: Modified Durie–Salmon staging is used for multiple myeloma.

questions.question: Question 20: Who among the following patients is likely to have the best prognosis?

options.a: A patient with mononuclear variant of Reed-Sternberg cells on lymph node biopsy
options.b: A patient whose lymph node biopsy showed lacunar Reed-Sternberg cells
options.c: A patient with predominant reticular variant of Reed- Sternberg cells
options.d: A patient with Reed-Sternberg cells amid mixed variety of background cells

questions.explanation:
The prognosis of the nodular sclerosis ( a subtype of classical Hodgkin lymphoma) is 
excellent compared to the other subtypes mentioned in the options. Lacunar Reed-Sternberg cells 
are seen in this condition. The nodular sclerosis type occurs with equal frequency in males and females. It has a propensity 
to involve the lower cervical, supraclavicular, and mediastinal lymph nodes of adolescents or 
young adults. Subtypes of Hodgkin's lymphoma along with their characteristic types of RS cells is given below: Nodular lymphocyte-predominant non-classical Hodgkin lymphoma also has an excellent 
prognosis. Diagnostic cells in histology 
Immunophenotype Hodgkin lymphoma (subty 
pes) Nodular sclerosis 
Lacunar variant 
CD 15+, CD 30 + CD 15+, CD 30 + Mixed cellularity 
Mononuclear and Diagnostic 
RS cells (70% EBV +) CD 15+, CD 30 + Lymphocyte Rich 
Mononuclear and Diagnostic 
RS cells (40% EBV -) CD 15+, CD 30 + Lymphocyte Depletion 
Reticular variant; (most EBV 
+) CD 20+, BCL6+CD 15 -, CD 3 
0 - Lymphocyte predominance 
Lymphocytic and histiocytic 
variant, popcorn cells (EBV -)

questions.question: Question 21: Which among the following is incorrect about Hodgkin's lymphoma?

options.a: Histologic type is the most important prognostic variable.
options.b: The cure rate of patients with stages I and IIA is close to 90%.
options.c: Long-term survivors treated with radiotherapy had a much higher incidence of secondary
options.d: It most commonly presents as painless lymphadenopathy.

questions.explanation:
With current treatment protocols, the tumor stage is the most important prognostic variable, not 
histologic type. Hodgkin's Lymphoma most commonly presents as painless lymphadenopathy. The cure rate of patients with stages I and IIA are close to 90%. Long-term survivors treated with radiotherapy had a much higher incidence of certain 
malignancies, such as lung cancer, melanoma, and breast cancer.

questions.question:
Question 22: Which of these parameters would be considered a poor prognostic factor in patients with 
Hodgkin's lymphoma?
questions.explanation:
499 
Sold by @itachibot Absolute lymphocyte count <600 cells/cumm is a poor prognostic factor for Hodgkin 
lymphoma. Poor prognostic factors for Hodgkin's lymphoma: • Age >45 years • Male gender • Haemoglobin <10.5 g/dl • Total WBC count >15000 cells/mm3 • Lymphocytopenia: absolute count <600/mm3 or lymphocytes <8% of leukocytes • Serum albumin level: <4g/dl • Stage IV 500 
Sold by @itachibot Non Hodgkin Lymphomas: General Considerations
